metadata.title: Performance evaluation of Ti–6Al–4V machining using nano-cutting fluids under minimum quantity lubrication

sections.text: Keywords Ti–6Al–4Valloy . Nano-fluid .Multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) . Tool wear . Machinability

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Several properties make titanium and its alloy the primary candidate to attain weight and functional advantages because of its superior properties (e.g., high strength to weight ratio, high corrosion resistivity, high yield stress, high wear resistance, and high toughness) [1]. A comparative study between Ti–6Al–4V, high-strength steel (34CrMo4), high-strength aluminum alloy (AlZnMg-Al7075), and high strength magnesium alloy (AZ80) has been presented in terms of their properties and applications. Ti–6Al–4V showed a significant advantage when structural components are designed for higher
strength or fatigue strength [2]. Although titanium alloys have superior properties, some inherent characteristics such as high chemical reactivity and low thermal conductivity lead to poor machinability and result in premature tool failure and shortened tool life. Furthermore, other major issues associated with machining of titanium alloys include generation of high mechanical pressure, high dynamic loads, high cutting temperature, and tendency to adhesion and forming built up edge [3, 4]. In view of their potential market, lots of large companies (e.g., Rolls Royce) present different studies to develop appropriate techniques for machining titanium alloys in order to minimize machining cost, achieve excellent surface quality, and achieve reasonable production rates by considering the unique characteristics of titanium alloys and developing new sustainable energy systems [4, 5].
The main factors that have an effect on machinability of titanium alloys are as follows: cutting parameters, mechanical properties of the material, design and properties of cutting tools, and cooling strategies. The most significant cutting parameters are cutting speed and feed rate. An increase in cutting speed accelerates tool wear and thereby tool failure. The feed rate has a major effect on surface roughness as decreasing feed
* H. Hegab Hussien.Hegab@uoit.ca
1 Machining Research Laboratory, UOIT, Oshawa, ON, Canada 2 Advanced Manufacturing Institute, King Saud University,
Riyadh, Saudi Arabia 3 Advanced Manufacturing Laboratory, University of Guelph,
Guelph, ON, Canada
rate improves the induced surface quality. Moreover, mechanical properties such as low thermal conductivity and high chemical reactivity can negatively influence the machinability. Due to the poor thermal conductivity, the cutting temperature elevates at tool/workpiece interface and concentrates along the cutting tool edge instead of diffusing into chips and workpiece. This results in high rate of tool wear and shorter tool life. Additionally, design and material properties of cutting tools are significant when addressing machinability. Cutting tool design such as rake and clearance angles play a significant role in the machining process. Some tools are specifically designed to dispose of chips to avoid adherence to the tool. For example, rotary tools were utilized and modeled in machining to reduce the wear since only a short segment of cutting edge is engaged with the workpiece [6].
Another important factor is the material type of cutting tool. The hardness of such materials is relatively high; therefore, the selection of suitable insert is necessary. Likewise, machining material under wet conditions (i.e., coolant strategy) can provide different results than machining under dry condition. The type of cooling strategy and how it is applied also influences the material machinability such as and tool life.
In addition, several problems can be taken place because of the inappropriate application of cutting fluids. Consequently, several studies have already been published in the open literature to introduce advanced cutting fluids techniques in order to improve the cutting fluid efficiency especially when machining difficult-to-cut materials. These materials have superior characteristics such as high strength to weight ratio, corrosion resistance, and temperature resistance that make them a material of choice in various industries (e.g., aerospace, automotive). Despite their desired features, the wide application of these materials has been compromised due to several difficulties that arise during their machining. One of best methods to protect the cutting tool during machining difficult-to-cut materials is the application of nano-cutting fluids technology as will be discussed in the next section.

sections.heading: 2 Nano-cutting fluid application
sections.text:
A nano-fluid can be defined as a new fluid results from the dispersion of metallic/nonmetallic nano-additives with a certain size less than 100 nm into the base cutting fluid [7]. Nanoadditives can be categorized into several types which are nonmetallic, mixing metallic, carbon, and ceramic nanoparticles [8]. Recently, some studies focused on adding multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) into the base fluid, and a noticeable enhancements in the proposed nano-fluid thermal conductivity has been observed [9]. In terms of the induced friction, it was found in a previous work [10] that addition of graphite nano-additives into the base lubricant showed an obvious reduction in the induced friction coefficient. Consequently, better surface quality
and lower cutting forces have been observed as a result of the improved friction behavior.
Additional study [11] confirmed that increasing nanoparticle concentration and decreasing nanoparticle size into the base cutting fluid has an effective role in improving thermal conduction during cutting processes. Also, previous studies have employed different nano-cutting fluids along with using minimum quantity lubrication (MQL), and promising results have been achieved in terms of improving the machining processes performance. For example, previous research [12] has used MoS2 nanoparticles with MQL to enhance the lubrication properties of different base oils when machining 45 steel. Another work [13] studied the effects of using MWCNT nano-fluids on the induced surface quality when grinding AISI D3 tool steel. MWCNT nano-fluids have been also employed in improving the machinability of EN 31 material [14]. Also, another study [15] employed hybrid nano-fluid (i.e., alumina with graphene nanoparticles) with MQL during turning AISI 304 steel, and the application of the hybrid nanofluid showed significant results in reducing the cutting forces, feed forces, and the surface roughness. Furthermore, additional studies [16, 17] obtained the significant effects of adding nano-additives on the tribological characteristics of the used base fluids. In addition, in a previous work [18], MWCNT nano-fluid under usingMQL system has employedwhen turning high carbon high chromium AISI D2 using tungsten carbide insert (CNMG 120408). Taguchi method was implemented to study the effects of cutting parameters on the
surface finish and cutting zone temperature. In comparison with classical MQL (without nano-additives), a better results observed when nano-additives based minimum quantity coolant has been employed. Another work [19] investigated the effects of MWCNTs/MQL system during high-speed milling of AISI 1050 and AISI P21. The results have been compared to dry cutting and wet cutting. It was that the MWCNT nanofluid showed an important role in improving the tool performance as well as the induced surface roughness because of the excellent heat conductivity of MWCNT nano-fluids.
Also, in a previous research [20], two nano-fluids (i.e., aluminaandMWCNTs)wereutilizedwhenhigh-speedturningofAISI 4140 steel with a TiN-top coated multi-layered carbide insert using small quantity lubrication (SQL) technology. A noticable reduction in the measured cutting forces and tensile residual stresses was reported. Furthermore, the induced surface quality was improved because of the resultant nano-fluids cooling and lubrication effects which retain the cutting tool edge sharpnesss.
Another study [21] worked on controlling the friction behavior when grinding Ti–6Al–4V using MQL system as the contact between the abrasive grains and work-piece is affecting the induced wheel wear and grinding forces. Different volume concentrations of Al2O3 and CuO nanoparticles were added to the base fluid (i.e., water). The employed nano-fluids effects on the wheel morphology, surface integrity, cutting forces, and coefficient of friction were investigated. The nano-cutting/ MQL system showed promising results in decreasing the induced friction, and tangential forces. Moreover, the short Ctype chip formation was observed; hence, it could indicate the cooling effect of the proposed lubrication system.
Achieving sustainable machining process is an essential requirement as it offers various environmental, societal and
economical advantages; however, enhancing the machining processes performance is still required besides building a sustainable environment. Thus, it is recommended that using nano-additives with vegetable oil as a base cutting fluid under using MQL system could establish the two desired objectives: enhancing the machining quality characteristics as nanoadditives improve the friction and thermal behavior and accomplishing a sustainable process as using vegetable oils provide effective environmental benefits. Also, it has been found from the literature review that there are only a few studies which investigated the nano-fluids effects when machining titanium alloys. The novelty here lies on enhancing the MQL heat capacity using nano-fluids to improve the Ti– 6Al–4V machinability. Thus, the focus of this research is mainly to study the effects of dispersed multi-wall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) into the conventional fluid (vegetable oil) under (MQL) technique during turning of Ti–6Al–4V alloy. Investigations are carried out to study the tool wear behavior and power consumption.

sections.heading: 3 Experimentation and methodology
sections.text:
Through conducting the cutting tests, which involved various speeds, feed rates, and weight percentages of added nano-additives, further examination of dispersed MWCNTs effects on the performance of MQL was possible. Ti–6Al–4V (UNS R56400) has been utilized as the used workpiece for experimentation. Chemical composition and some other properties for Ti–6Al–4V (UNS R56400) are listed in Table 1.
The cutting insert information is listed in Table 2. To expand further, the depth cut was set at 0.2 mm and sensitivity analysis
Symbol Level 1 Level 2 Level 3
was incorporated in order to better understand the cutting conditions effects throughout the process. Through the use and installation of a stand-alone booster system (Eco-Lubric) onto themachine tool,anair–oilmixtureofferedanominal flowrateof40ml/ h and air pressure of 0.5 MPa, similarly as used in a previous research work [22]. This base cutting fluid, ECOLUBRIC E200, is composedof vegetable oil devoid of additives, allowing this cold-pressed rapeseed oil to not only assist in carrying out favorable outcomes when used in these specific tests, but also provide less abrasive effects on the environment.
Multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) with 13– 20 nm average diameter, 95% purity, 10–30 μm length, and 110 m2/g specific surface area were used for nano-cutting fluid preparations [23]. Dispersion of MWCNTs into the base cutting fluid is an important factor which affects the resultant nano-cutting fluid thermal conductivity and viscosity. The dispersion of MWCNTs into the base cutting fluid is performed using an ultrasonic device (AQUASONIC-50HT) over the course of 3 h at 60 °C, which is then followed by a step that offers thoroughmixture, using a magnetic stirrer (Hot Plate Stirrer-3073-21) for 30 min to ensure full dispersion of MWCNTs into the resultant nano-cutting fluid. Nano-additive dispersion into the base fluid is an important consideration which affects the thermal conductivity and viscosity of the resultant nano-cutting fluid. Also, dispersion of nanoadditives into the base fluid is considered as a difficult challenge due to the strong van derWaals interactions which result in nano-additives agglomeration, clogging, and sedimentation. Two techniques are usually used to evaluate the nanoadditives suspension quality into the base oil, namely,
diffusion and zeta potential. Regarding the diffusion technique, it mainly ensures that the nano-additives are scattered and dispersed into the liquid medium, while zeta technique is focusing on achieving higher values which represent the repulsive force among the nano-additives [24].
In thisstudy,zetapotential forstabilityanalysiswasperformed to characterize the nano-cutting fluid suspension stability. The Zetasizer-nano-device is used to determine the zeta potential absolute values for the resultant nano-fluids using different weight percentages of MWCNTs. Also, sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) has been used in preparing the nano-fluid as a surfactant (i.e., 0.2 g). The purpose of using a surfactant is enhancing the nanoadditives performance to bemore hydrophilic and increasing the nano-additives surface charges; hence, the repulsive forces between thenano-additives are increased as it hasbeendiscussed in some previous studies [25, 26]. Following each cutting test, data regarding flank wear, and power consumption were obtained. Through the use of a toolmaker’s microscope, flank wear was measured subsequent to each cutting pass. In addition, a Power SightManagerwas employed throughout themachiningprocess in effort to assist with logging power consumption. The experimental setup flow chart is shown in Fig. 1.
In this investigation, three design variables were employed with three levels each. Table 3 indicates the studied independent process parameters and the assignment of the corresponding levels for Ti–6Al–4V cutting processes. L9 orthogonal array (L9OA) based on the Taguchi method was implemented for cutting tests. L9OA has nine rows corresponding to the number of tests with four columns at three levels. Tests were replicated three times and average values of measured responses were obtained. The full-factorial array in this study is L27OA (33); however, fractional factorial array L9OA based on the design of experiments approach was implemented to save time and cost. The conducted tests consist of nine experiments in which the first column was assigned to the cutting speed, the second column to the feed rate, and the third column to the weight percentage of added nano-additives as shown in Table 4.
The nano-fluid usage when employing flood coolant can be a harmful concern; however, when using MQL technique, an optimal amount of oil is used resulting in a very fine mist where certain procedure is followed to eliminate any concern of using the nano-additives. Also, during the experimentation phase, certain safety procedures (i.e., standard nano-additives safety data sheets) have been applied to maintain a standard health and safety level in the workshop to avoid any harmful impacts for the machine operator. Regarding the disposal method, the nano-fluids have been carefully filtered before being released to the sewer according to a standard material safety data sheet [27].

sections.heading: 4 Results and discussions
sections.text:
The zeta potential results for the employed nano-cutting fluids are listed in Table 5. It was found that all values are in the range of moderate stability, according to the suspension
stability evaluation criteria [28]. Two machining characteristics results are presented and discussed in this section, namely, flank wear (VB) and power consumption.

sections.heading: 4.1 Tool wear
sections.text:
The flank wear results when cutting Ti–6Al–4V with MWCNT nano-fluid are provided in Fig. 2. Amaximum flank wear of 0.4 mm [29] is used as the tool life criteria; otherwise, in case of not reaching the end of tool life criteria, the cutting stopped after nine cutting passes. The tool wear results are provided as shown in Table 6. The results revealed that MWCNT nano-fluid has shown promising results in comparison with the tests performed without any nano-additives (i.e., tests 1, 6, and 8). Test 3 shows the lowest flank wear value. The cutting conditions at test 3 are cutting speed of 120 m/ min, feed rate of 0.15mm/rev, and 4 wt% of addedMWCNTs. The highest wear value was found after test 8 (after six cutting passes) and after test 6 (after five cutting passes). Both of cutting tests 8 and 6 have been performed without using nano-additives. Also, the tool wear progress is presented as shown in Fig. 3.
The nano-fluid significant improvements are mainly attributed to the significant cooling and lubrication properties of nanofluids which improve the rake and flank regions’ lubrication and wetting properties so that better heat dissipation was accomplished. Thus, partially smoothed cutting processes was achieved and lower flank wear values were observed in comparisonwith the processes performedwithout any nano-additives as has been discussed in previous studies [30, 31]. Also, the mentioned characteristics enormously improve the cooling and lubrication properties which retain the cutting tool hardness for a longer time as similarly confirmed in previous works [32, 33].
Analysis of variance (ANOVA) has been used in the current work to study the machining design variables effects on both tool wear and power consumption. ANOVA has been employed in previous studies [34, 35],, and it was an effective tool to clearly obtain the significant machining parameters affecting different machining characteristics.

ANOVA results for the flank wear are listed in Table 7. It is revealed that weight percentage of added nanoadditives is the main significant design variable affects the flank wear at 90% confidence level; however, cutting speed still has an acceptable statistical summation in comparison with the feed rate which can show the cutting speed effect on the induced tool wear (see Table 7). Also, Fig. 4 visually confirms the noticeable effect of cutting speed on the flank wear. Within the range of the investigated independent variables, the optimal levels were found to be cutting speed of 120 m/min, feed rate of 0.15 mm/rev, and 4 wt% of added MWCNTs (see Fig. 4). It was concluded also from Fig. 4 that 4 and 2 wt% of added MWCT reduced the flank wear by 49.4 and 45%, respectively, in comparison with the tests performed without any nano-additives (classical MQL).
Also, the modes of tool wear and their associated wear mechanisms are presented and discussed in this section. All micrographs of worn faces were captured at the end of cutting tests. The dominant wear modes when cutting under mist coolant without nano-additives were as follows: excessive flank wear, crater wear, tool nose wear, and plastic deformation. Regarding the tests performed using nano-additives either using MWCNTs or Al2O3 nanofluids, it was demonstrated that the dominant wear modes were flank wear and crater.
The employed nano-fluids (i.e., MWCNTs) showed significant improvements in reducing both flank and crater wear compared to the tests performed without nanoadditives as shown in Figs. 5 and 6, respectively. The crater wear is related to the diffusive wear mechanism as the rake face materials is dissolved into the generated chip due to the high-generated temperature during cutting processes (i.e., dissolution-diffusion) as discussed in a previous work [3]. On the other hand, the abrasion between the workpiece and the tool surface is main reason for the observed flank wear during cutting without MWCNTs. Regarding the employed nano-fluids significant effects,
it is mainly due to the promising cooling and lubrication properties which enhance the interface bonding between tool and workpiece surfaces so that the abrasive wear severity is partially eliminated and the high-generated temperature is significantly decreased [36, 37].
Regarding the tool nose wear (see Fig. 7a), it is mainly attributed to an excessive localized damage on both the rake and flank faces appeared at the tool nose. It has been claimed in a previous study [38] that it is attributed to the abrasive wear mechanism because of the hard constituents in the workpiece material. Also, the plastic deformation was observed as can be seen in Fig. 7b. It is mainly due to the high generated temperature as the thermal shock mechanism leads to softening the tool material and resulting in cracks developments and plastic deformation wear.

sections.heading: 4.2 Power consumption results
sections.text:
The power consumption results when using MWCNT nano-fluid are provided in Fig. 8 and Table 8. When 2 wt% of added MWCNs is utilized, the results showed that cutting test 2 offered the lowest power consumption. The cutting conditions at this test are cutting speed of 120 m/min and feed rate of 0.15 mm/rev, while the highest power consumption value has been obtained at cutting test 8 which has been performed using classical MQL without nano-additives. In general, MWCNT nanofluid has shown better performance in reducing the power consumption compared to the tests performed without any nano-additives.
Due to the high induced friction occurred during machining of difficult-to-cut materials, the higher frictional force component would lead to adhesive friction, and therefore, the flow of chips will take place only within the workpiece (not at the tool–workpiece interface). Consequently, the deformed chip thickness would increase and accordingly, the cutting ratio and shear angle would decrease. Therefore, the cutting force component required to remove the chip would significantly increase [39, 40]. Thus, applying an appropriate lubrication and cooling system to the tool–chip interface is required in order to reduce the induced coefficient of friction. The significant tribological properties of the resultant nano-cutting fluid could help in reducing the coefficient of friction at the tool–chip interface since the employed nano-additives work as spacers and decrease the induced rubbing between the cutting tool and workpiece (see Fig. 9) [32, 41].
The ANOVA results (see Table 9) have shown that cutting speed and weight percent of added nanoadditives were the main significant design variables that affect the power consumption at 99% confidence levels. In addition, the plot of the design variable effects is
shown in Fig. 10 and it is demonstrated that cutting speed of 120 m/min, feed rate of 0.1 mm/rev, and 2 wt% of added nano-additives were the optimal levels which offer the lowest power consumption when MWCNT nano-fluid was employed. However, the cutting feed rate has not shown any significant effects (see Fig. 10 and Table 9).
From Fig. 10, it can be concluded that of 4 wt% of added MWCNTs reduced the power consumption by 7.9% compared to the tests performed without nano-additives (i.e., C3 vs. C1), while 2 wt% of added MWCNTs reduced the generated power by 11.5% (i.e., C2 vs. C1).
However, increasing the added percentage of nano-additives increases the resultant nano-fluid thermal conductivity and
accordingly improves the heat transfer performance, 2 wt% offered less power consumption than 4wt%. This finding could be attributed to the nano-additives dispersion into the base fluid (e.g., agglomeration, clogging, or sedimentation); however, zeta potential results offered an acceptable performance for both nano-additives percentages as has been mentioned earlier (see Table 5). On the other hand, 4 wt% MWCNTs offered better results in reducing the flank wear compared to 2 wt% of added MWCNTs. Thus, more investigations need to be focused on the effect of nano-additives concentration on the nano-cutting fluid tribological and heat transfer mechanisms in order to physically justify why 2 wt% nano-fluid occasionally offers better cutting performance than 4 wt% nano-fluid.
Fig. 6 The observed flank tool wear at cutting speed of 170 m/ min and feed rate of 0.1 mm /rev using a without nano-additives and b 2 wt%MWCNT nano-fluid

sections.heading: 4.3 MQL-Nano-fluid mechanism
sections.text:
Understanding the MQL nano-fluid mechanisms is highly required in order to physically clarify the nano-cutting fluids significant improvements on the cutting performance. The MQL nano-fluid mechanism is concluded as follows (see Fig. 9):
1. The nano-fluid is atomized into the MQL nozzle through the applied compressed air, and it results in a very fine mist. 2. This mist represents the nano-additives surrounded by a thin base fluid film. This mist can penetrate the cutting zone as its velocity is significantly larger than cutting tool velocity since it can pass through the tool pores and grain fractured groves. 3. Therefore, the nano-fluid droplets are settled on the workpiece surface as well as the cutting tool and a tribo-film is formed which significantly improves the lubrication effects and reduces the generated friction.
4. Nano-additives serve as spacers, eliminating the contact between tool and workpiece. Thus, amplifying the nanoadditive concentrations allows for frictional behavior enhancement at the tool-workpiece interface. This lubrication effect has been called rolling mechanism as has been mentioned in a previous work [42] which studied the lubrication mechanism using disk-on-disk tester with mineral oil and fullerene nano-additives. 5. The plowed-off nano-additives formed a thin exfoliated layer on the tool–workpiece interface area because of the nano-additives collisions as well as the high compressed pressure at the cutting zone as mentioned before in a previous study [43].
Cutting test no. Cutting speed (m/min)
Feed rate (mm/ rev) Percentage of added MWCNTs (wt%)
Power consumption (Watt h)
6. Since the plowed-off nano-additives formed a thin exfoliated layer on the tool–workpiece interface area, the formation of a protective nano-additive thin film on the machined surface could be noticed and that prevents the induced cutting temperature from dissipating into the workpiece material. As a result, large amounts of heat generated in the cutting zone alter the elasto-hydrodynamic lubrication to boundary lubrication.

sections.heading: 4.4 ANOVA verification results
sections.text:
In order to verify the developed ANOVA results, Eq. (1) has been employed to estimate the optimal predicted responses values as follows:
Ypredicted ¼ Ymean þ ∑ n
i¼1 Y i−Ymeanð Þ ð1Þ
where Yi is the average response at the optimal design variable level, and Ymean is the overall mean value. The verification results are calculated as obtained in Table 10. Good agreement can be noticed between the predicted and experimental optimal results (see Table 10).

sections.heading: 4.5 Machining quality characteristics modeling
sections.text:
The modeling of the studied cutting processes is implemented using response surface methodology (RSM) to study the effects of the studied design variables on the measured responses. RSM has been employed in previous studies to optimize the machining parameters effects on different machining characteristics [44]. The developed models are used to express the generated power consumption and flank wear. The purpose of mathematical models relates the process responses to ease the optimization of the process. The model’s validation is demonstrated using the average percentage of deviation (Δ) which can be calculated as shown in Eqs. (2–3), where Rm is the measured response, Rp is the predicted response, n is the number of runs, and Δi is the percentage of deviation per run (i).
Δi ¼ Abs Rm−RpRm
100% ð2Þ
Δ ¼ ∑ n i¼1Δi n
ð3Þ
RSM technique is implemented to model the studied cutting processes. The developed models using MWCNT nanofluid for flank wear and power consumption are provided as shown in Eqs. (4–5), respectively.
The design variable quadratic and interaction effects are used to express the developed model as all studied design variables have three levels (second degree of freedom). The average model accuracy for the flank wear under using MWCNT nano-fluid is about 89.31%, while 98.6% average model accuracy is calculated for the power consumption model. The 3-D surface plots for all measured responses are provided as shown in Figs. 11 and 12. In all 3-D surface plots, the third design variable is held constant at its second level. As can be seen in Fig. 11b, c, increasing MWCNT percentage results in decreasing the flank wear. Also, Fig. 11b, c shows an agreement with the results obtained in Fig. 4 as both of them confirmed that 4 wt% MWCNTs provides the lowest flank wear. In addition, Fig. 11a confirmed the previous
Table 10 ANOVA verification results

findings in Table 7 and Fig. 4 since changing the cutting speed levels showed significant effects on the flank wear results. From Fig. 12b, c, it was found that 2 wt% provided the lowest power consumption values. This finding is in agreement with the results obtained in Fig. 10. Also, as can be seen in Fig. 12a, the cutting speed showed significant effect on the power consumption values; however, the feed rate did not show noticeable effects. This finding is consistent also with the power consumption ANOVA results presented in Table 9.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text:
In this work, MWCNT nano-fluid has been employed during machining of Ti–6Al–4V in order to study their influence on tool wear and cutting power consumption. The work findings have been concluded as follows:
1. It was demonstrated that percentage of added nanoadditives is a significant design variable affecting both flank wear and power consumption using ANOVA. 2. It was observed that MWCNT nano-fluid offered better results in terms of tool wear and power consumption compared to the tests performed without nano-additives (pure MQL). 3. Four weight percent of added MWCNTs offered the lowest flank wear value; however, 2 wt% nano-fluid offered better performance than 4 wt% nano-fluid for power consumption results.
4. Two mathematical models have been developed to express the studied cutting responses based on the studied design variables range, and acceptable average accuracy has been obtained for each proposed model. 5. MWCNT nano-fluids have shown promising results in enhancing the cutting tool performance. It is mainly due to enhancing the interface bonding between the tool and workpiece surfaces. Also, MWCNT significant improvements are mainly attributed to the significant cooling and lubrication properties of nano-fluids which improve the rake and flank regions’ lubrication and wetting properties and, consequently, partially smooth cutting processes have been achieved. 6. More investigations need to be focused on the effects of nano-additive concentration and size on the nano-fluid tribological and heat transfer mechanisms in order to physically justify why 2 wt% nano-fluid sometimes offers better cutting performance than 4 wt% nano-fluid.
Funding information The authors acknowledge the support of the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC) and the International Scientific Partnership Program ISPP at King Saud University for funding this research work through ISPP# 0059.

metadata.abstractText: Owing to their superior mechanical, physical, and chemical characteristics, titanium and its alloys are broadly used in different industrial applications such as military, aerospace, power generation, and automotive. However, titanium alloys are inherently difficult to cut materials due to the high generated temperature during machining. In addition to flood cooling, several other techniques were employed to reduce the harmful effect and the generated temperature and generally improve titanium alloys machinability. In this paper, an attempt is made to utilize nano-additives to improve the cooling efficiency of minimum quantity lubrication (MQL) during machining titanium alloys. The main objective of the current research is to investigate the influence of dispersed multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) into vegetable oil by implementing the MQL technique during turning of Ti–6Al–4V. The novelty here lies on enhancing the MQL heat capacity using different concentrations of nano-fluid in order to improve Ti–6Al–4V machinability. Different cutting tests were performed and relevant data were collected. The studied design variables were cutting speed, feed rate, and percentage of added nano-additives (wt%). It was found that 2 wt% MWCNT nanofluid reduced the power consumption by 11.5% in comparison with tests performed without any nano-additives, while the same concentration reduced the flank wear by 45%.
